componentTest.name: NTC Thermistor
componentTest.procedure:
1. POWER OFF
2. Disconnect thermistor
3. Measure at room temp: ~10kΩ
4. Warm with hand: drops to 7-8kΩ
5. Check cable continuity
componentTest.passFail: PASS: 9.7-10.3kΩ @ 25°C; Drops when warmed | FAIL: OL/short; No change
componentTest.safety: ⚠️ Power OFF; System may be HOT

6. Listen for click

componentTest.safety: ⚠️ GAS SAFE ONLY; 230V SHOCK HAZARD; Gas leak risk

componentTest.name: Fan Motor

2. Check spins freely
3. Measure resistance: 100-500Ω
4. Power ON
5. Measure voltage: 230V AC
6. Fan starts within 5s
componentTest.passFail: PASS: Spins freely; Correct resistance; 230V; Runs | FAIL: Seized; OL; No voltage
componentTest.safety: ⚠️ 230V SHOCK; Spinning blades

componentTest.name: Pressure Sensor/Switch
componentTest.expectedVoltage: Sensor: 5V DC supply, 0.5-4.5V signal | Switch: N/A
componentTest.procedure:
1. POWER OFF
2. Locate pressure component
3. Test sensor voltage at different pressures
4. Test switch continuity at >1 bar
5. Verify operation
componentTest.passFail: PASS: Sensor voltage changes with pressure; Switch closes >0.8bar | FAIL: Stuck readings; Always open/closed
componentTest.safety: ⚠️ 230V AC present; System pressurized; Power OFF before work

diagnosticSteps: Check boiler temperature - frost mode activates below 5°C
Verify boiler location isn't excessively cold (garage, loft)
Check central heating programmer is set correctly
Ensure room thermostat is on and set above current temperature
Monitor boiler - should return to normal when temperature rises above 12°C
If frost mode doesn't clear, check flow thermistor operation
possibleCauses: Normal operation - boiler protecting itself from freezing
Room thermostat set too low or off
F.solution: This is normally automatic protection and requires no action. Boiler will periodically fire to maintain temperature above 5°C. Ensure adequate boiler room temperature. If fault persists above 12°C, check flow thermistor.

diagnosticSteps: Check system pressure: must be 1-1.5 bar
Listen/feel for pump operation during heating demand
Check pump power supply: 230V AC when demand present
Remove pump head and manually spin to check for seizure
Inspect flow switch - ensure paddle moves freely
Check for system blockages: feel flow and return pipes during operation
Bleed radiators to remove air locks
Clean flow switch and check micro-switch operation
possibleCauses: Central heating pump not running or seized
Flow switch paddle/vane obstructed by debris
FD.solution: If pump seized, free or replace pump. If flow switch faulty, replace switch. If air locked, bleed system thoroughly. If system blockage, powerflush may be required. Ensure system pressure at 1.5 bar.

diagnosticSteps: Check pressure gauge - should read 1.0-1.5 bar when cold
If gauge shows <1 bar, visually inspect for leaks at radiator valves, pipe joints, and boiler connections
If no visible leaks, repressurise system using filling loop beneath boiler
Open left blue valve (mains water) then slowly open right valve (heating system)
Watch pressure gauge rise to 1.5 bar then close both valves immediately
If F1 persists with correct pressure (1-2 bar), test pressure sensor/transducer
If pressure drops repeatedly, use leak detection dye or pressure test to locate hidden leak
possibleCauses: System leak in radiators, pipework, or boiler components
Filling loop valves not properly closed
Faulty pressure sensor giving false readings
Air pockets in the system after bleeding radiators
Pressure relief valve releasing excess pressure
F1.solution: Repressurise system to 1.5 bar using filling loop. If pressure drops repeatedly, locate and repair leak before repressurising. Replace faulty pressure sensor if F1 shows with correct pressure.

diagnosticSteps: Check gas supply is ON at meter and emergency control valve
Test gas pressure at burner: 18-20 mbar for natural gas
Inspect electrode gap with feeler gauge: must be 3-4mm from burner
Test ignition lead resistance using multimeter: <200Ω acceptable
Remove and clean condensate trap - check for blockages
Inspect flue terminal for blockages (birds nests, debris)
Test gas valve coil resistance: 2.8-4.5kΩ normal range
Check flame sense electrode is clean and properly positioned
Test for flame rectification signal: should show microamps
possibleCauses: Gas supply interrupted or insufficient pressure (should be 18-20 mbar)
Electrode incorrectly positioned (3-4mm gap from burner required)
Faulty or damaged ignition lead (resistance should be <200Ω)
Condensate trap blocked causing flue pressure issues
F2.solution: Repair or replace faulty component identified in diagnostic steps. Most common: clean condensate trap, adjust electrode gap to 3-4mm, or replace faulty ignition lead. If gas valve faulty, requires Gas Safe engineer replacement.

diagnosticSteps: Listen for fan operation during startup - should hear distinct whirring
Check fan PCB connector is secure and pins clean
Inspect venturi tube for blockages, webs, debris
Remove and clean air pressure switch diaphragm
Test fan motor windings: typically 30-50Ω resistance
Manually spin fan - should rotate freely with no grinding
Use manometer to test air pressure switch operation
Check flue for blockages (birds nests, leaves)
Measure fan speed with tachometer if available
possibleCauses: Fan motor failure (bearing seized or winding fault)
Air pressure switch faulty or stuck
Venturi tube blocked with debris or spider webs
Fan PCB connector loose or corroded
F3.solution: Clean venturi tube and air pressure switch. If fan motor seized or faulty (no/high resistance, won't spin), replace fan assembly. If air pressure switch faulty, replace switch. Clear any flue blockages. Ensure all connections secure.

componentTest.name: Fan Motor
componentTest.procedure:

3. Measure resistance: 100-500Ω
4. Power ON
5. Measure voltage: 230V AC
6. Fan starts within 5s
componentTest.passFail: PASS: Spins freely; Correct resistance; 230V; Runs | FAIL: Seized; OL; No voltage
componentTest.safety: ⚠️ 230V SHOCK; Spinning blades

diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler and isolate electrically
Locate flow thermistor (typically on flow pipe from heat exchanger)
Disconnect thermistor connector and inspect for corrosion
Test thermistor resistance at room temperature: should read 10-12kΩ at 20°C
Heat sensor gently (e.g., in hand) - resistance should DROP as temperature rises
Check wiring continuity from sensor to PCB connector
Ensure sensor is properly inserted into thermistor pocket with thermal paste
If sensor tests OK, check PCB connections and test PCB NTC input
possibleCauses: Flow thermistor sensor failed (open circuit or short circuit)
Wiring damaged between sensor and PCB
Sensor not properly seated in thermistor pocket
Thermistor reading out of range due to limescale buildup
F4.solution: Replace flow thermistor if resistance is incorrect (<5kΩ or >50kΩ) or doesn't change with temperature. Ensure connector is clean and sensor is properly seated with thermal paste. If sensor tests OK, fault is likely PCB.

diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler and isolate electrically
Locate return thermistor (on return pipe to boiler)
Disconnect thermistor connector and inspect for corrosion/damage
Test thermistor resistance at room temperature: should read 10-12kΩ at 20°C
Heat sensor gently - resistance should DROP smoothly as temp rises
Check wiring continuity from sensor to PCB
Ensure sensor properly inserted in pocket with thermal paste
Compare flow and return thermistor readings - should be similar at cold
If sensor tests OK, check PCB NTC input circuit
possibleCauses: Return thermistor sensor failed (open circuit or short circuit)
Thermistor connector loose, corroded, or damaged
Wiring damaged between sensor and PCB
Sensor not properly seated in thermistor pocket
Large temperature differential between flow and return (>35°C)
PCB fault affecting NTC input circuit
F5.solution: Replace return thermistor if resistance incorrect or doesn't change with temperature. Ensure connector clean and sensor properly seated with thermal paste. If sensor OK but fault persists, likely PCB fault requiring board replacement.

diagnosticSteps: Locate outside sensor (usually mounted on external north-facing wall)
Check sensor is securely connected and connector is dry
Inspect wiring for damage from weather, rodents, or drilling
Test sensor resistance: should vary with temperature (typically 10kΩ at 20°C)
Check sensor is not in direct sunlight or near heat source
Test wiring continuity from sensor to boiler PCB
If sensor tests OK, check PCB external sensor input circuit
possibleCauses: External temperature sensor faulty or disconnected
Sensor incorrectly positioned (in direct sunlight, etc.)
F6.solution: Replace external sensor if faulty. Repair damaged wiring. Ensure sensor is correctly positioned away from direct sunlight and heat sources. Note: Boiler will operate normally but may be less efficient without weather compensation.

diagnosticSteps: Check system pressure on gauge: must be >1 bar
Listen/feel for pump vibration during heating demand
Check pump power supply: should have 230V AC when running
Remove pump head and manually spin impeller to check for seizure
Increase pump speed to maximum and test
Check flow and return pipes - should both get hot when heating demand
Test flow thermistor: 10-12kΩ at room temp (disconnect and test)
Check for system blockages: flush system if necessary
Inspect heat exchanger for limescale buildup
possibleCauses: Central heating system blockage restricting flow
Thermistor fault giving false high temperature reading
Heat exchanger blocked with limescale (esp. in hard water areas)
Air lock in system preventing circulation
L1.solution: If pump seized, remove pump head, clean and lubricate or replace pump. If system blockage, powerflush required. If low pressure, repressurise to 1.5 bar. If thermistor faulty, replace. If heat exchanger scaled, descale or replace heat exchanger.

diagnosticSteps: Verify gas supply: check meter and emergency control valve are ON
Test gas pressure at test point: 18-20 mbar for natural gas, 37 mbar for LPG
Inspect electrode gap: 3-4mm from burner (use feeler gauge)
Test ignition lead: <200Ω resistance, no visible cracks/tracking
Remove and empty condensate trap, clean if necessary
Clean burner and flame sense electrode with wire brush
Check flame rectification circuit: microamp reading when flame present
Reset boiler after repairs - lockout resets after successful ignition
possibleCauses: No gas supply or gas valve closed
Gas pressure too low (<18 mbar at burner)
Ignition lead failure (high resistance or tracking)
Flame sense electrode contaminated or incorrectly positioned
L2.solution: Address cause of ignition failure: adjust electrode gap to 3-4mm, replace ignition lead if faulty, empty condensate trap, or replace gas valve if coil faulty. After fixing root cause, reset boiler to clear lockout.

diagnosticSteps: Note which fault codes appeared before L5 lockout
Check fault history on boiler display (access diagnostic mode per manual)
Test gas pressure under load: must remain 18-20 mbar during operation
Monitor flame through viewing window for stability
Test flame rectification signal: should be steady microamps
Check condensate trap isn't repeatedly filling/blocking
Test electrical supply: 230V AC stable with no voltage drops
Monitor boiler through full heating cycle to identify intermittent fault
Check system pressure doesn't fluctuate during operation
possibleCauses: Intermittent flame loss (investigate as per F2 fault)
Low gas pressure causing unreliable ignition
Faulty flame sense electrode giving intermittent signal
Electrical supply issues causing boiler resets
PCB fault causing false error readings
Overheating due to pump/circulation fault (see L1)
L5.solution: L5 is a symptom, not root cause. Identify and fix the underlying fault causing repeated resets (usually F2, L1, or L2). Common fixes: stabilize gas pressure, replace flame sense electrode, or resolve circulation issues. Reset after fixing root cause.

L6.description: False flame detection (flame before gas valve)
diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler - this is a safety-critical fault
Inspect flame sense electrode for contamination - clean with wire brush
Check electrode gap and position per manufacturer spec
Inspect PCB for water damage, corrosion, or burn marks
Test gas valve: should have NO continuity across solenoid when powered off
Check for gas smell at burner when boiler off (gas valve leak)
Test flame rectification circuit with boiler powered but NOT firing
Inspect electrode lead for cracks, tracking, or damaged insulation
possibleCauses: Flame sense electrode contaminated or incorrect gap
Water ingress on PCB causing false rectification signal
Faulty gas valve allowing gas through when closed
Electrode lead tracking or poor insulation
Burner contamination causing phantom flame signal
L6.solution: SAFETY CRITICAL: False flame detection indicates unsafe condition. Clean flame electrode. If PCB shows water damage, replace PCB. If gas valve allows gas through when closed, replace gas valve immediately. Do NOT operate boiler until fault resolved.

Check fault history on boiler display (access diagnostic mode per manual)
Test gas pressure under load: must remain 18-20 mbar during operation

Monitor boiler through full heating cycle to identify intermittent fault

L5.solution: L5 is a symptom, not root cause. Identify and fix the underlying fault causing repeated resets (usually F2, L1, or L2). Common fixes: stabilize gas pressure, replace flame sense electrode, or resolve circulation issues. Reset after fixing root cause.

diagnosticSteps: Check boiler temperature - frost mode activates below 5°C
Verify boiler location isn't excessively cold (garage, loft)
Check central heating programmer is set correctly
Ensure room thermostat is on and set above current temperature
Monitor boiler - should return to normal when temperature rises above 12°C
If frost mode doesn't clear, check flow thermistor operation
possibleCauses: Normal operation - boiler protecting itself from freezing
Room thermostat set too low or off
F.solution: This is normally automatic protection and requires no action. Boiler will periodically fire to maintain temperature above 5°C. Ensure adequate boiler room temperature. If fault persists above 12°C, check flow thermistor.

diagnosticSteps: Check pressure gauge - should read 1.0-1.5 bar when cold
If gauge shows <1 bar, visually inspect for leaks at radiator valves, pipe joints, and boiler connections
If no visible leaks, repressurise system using filling loop beneath boiler
Open left blue valve (mains water) then slowly open right valve (heating system)
Watch pressure gauge rise to 1.5 bar then close both valves immediately
If F1 persists with correct pressure (1-2 bar), test pressure sensor/transducer
If pressure drops repeatedly, use leak detection dye or pressure test to locate hidden leak
possibleCauses: System leak in radiators, pipework, or boiler components
Filling loop valves not properly closed
Faulty pressure sensor giving false readings
Air pockets in the system after bleeding radiators
Pressure relief valve releasing excess pressure
F1.solution: Repressurise system to 1.5 bar using filling loop. If pressure drops repeatedly, locate and repair leak before repressurising. Replace faulty pressure sensor if F1 shows with correct pressure.

diagnosticSteps: Check gas supply is ON at meter and emergency control valve
Test gas pressure at burner: 18-20 mbar for natural gas
Inspect electrode gap with feeler gauge: must be 3-4mm from burner
Test ignition lead resistance using multimeter: <200Ω acceptable
Remove and clean condensate trap - check for blockages
Inspect flue terminal for blockages (birds nests, debris)
Test gas valve coil resistance: 2.8-4.5kΩ normal range
Check flame sense electrode is clean and properly positioned
Test for flame rectification signal: should show microamps
possibleCauses: Gas supply interrupted or insufficient pressure (should be 18-20 mbar)
Electrode incorrectly positioned (3-4mm gap from burner required)
Faulty or damaged ignition lead (resistance should be <200Ω)
Condensate trap blocked causing flue pressure issues
F2.solution: Repair or replace faulty component identified in diagnostic steps. Most common: clean condensate trap, adjust electrode gap to 3-4mm, or replace faulty ignition lead. If gas valve faulty, requires Gas Safe engineer replacement.

diagnosticSteps: Listen for fan operation during startup - should hear distinct whirring
Check fan PCB connector is secure and pins clean
Inspect venturi tube for blockages, webs, debris
Remove and clean air pressure switch diaphragm
Test fan motor windings: typically 30-50Ω resistance
Manually spin fan - should rotate freely with no grinding
Use manometer to test air pressure switch operation
Check flue for blockages (birds nests, leaves)
Measure fan speed with tachometer if available
possibleCauses: Fan motor failure (bearing seized or winding fault)
Air pressure switch faulty or stuck
Venturi tube blocked with debris or spider webs
Fan PCB connector loose or corroded

diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler and isolate electrically
Locate flow thermistor (typically on flow pipe from heat exchanger)
Disconnect thermistor connector and inspect for corrosion
Test thermistor resistance at room temperature: should read 10-12kΩ at 20°C
Heat sensor gently (e.g., in hand) - resistance should DROP as temperature rises
Check wiring continuity from sensor to PCB connector
Ensure sensor is properly inserted into thermistor pocket with thermal paste
If sensor tests OK, check PCB connections and test PCB NTC input
possibleCauses: Flow thermistor sensor failed (open circuit or short circuit)
Wiring damaged between sensor and PCB
Sensor not properly seated in thermistor pocket
Thermistor reading out of range due to limescale buildup
F4.solution: Replace flow thermistor if resistance is incorrect (<5kΩ or >50kΩ) or doesn't change with temperature. Ensure connector is clean and sensor is properly seated with thermal paste. If sensor tests OK, fault is likely PCB.

diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler and isolate electrically
Locate return thermistor (on return pipe to boiler)
Disconnect thermistor connector and inspect for corrosion/damage
Test thermistor resistance at room temperature: should read 10-12kΩ at 20°C
Heat sensor gently - resistance should DROP smoothly as temp rises
Check wiring continuity from sensor to PCB
Ensure sensor properly inserted in pocket with thermal paste
Compare flow and return thermistor readings - should be similar at cold
If sensor tests OK, check PCB NTC input circuit
possibleCauses: Return thermistor sensor failed (open circuit or short circuit)
Thermistor connector loose, corroded, or damaged
Wiring damaged between sensor and PCB
Sensor not properly seated in thermistor pocket
Large temperature differential between flow and return (>35°C)
PCB fault affecting NTC input circuit
F5.solution: Replace return thermistor if resistance incorrect or doesn't change with temperature. Ensure connector clean and sensor properly seated with thermal paste. If sensor OK but fault persists, likely PCB fault requiring board replacement.

L1.description: Overheat lockout / Flow temperature too high
diagnosticSteps: Check system pressure on gauge: must be >1 bar
Listen/feel for pump vibration during heating demand
Check pump power supply: should have 230V AC when running
Remove pump head and manually spin impeller to check for seizure
Increase pump speed to maximum and test
Check flow and return pipes - should both get hot when heating demand
Test flow thermistor: 10-12kΩ at room temp (disconnect and test)
Check for system blockages: flush system if necessary
Inspect heat exchanger for limescale buildup
possibleCauses: Central heating system blockage restricting flow
Thermistor fault giving false high temperature reading
Heat exchanger blocked with limescale (esp. in hard water areas)
Air lock in system preventing circulation
L1.solution: If pump seized, remove pump head, clean and lubricate or replace pump. If system blockage, powerflush required. If low pressure, repressurise to 1.5 bar. If thermistor faulty, replace. If heat exchanger scaled, descale or replace heat exchanger.

Test gas pressure at test point: 18-20 mbar for natural gas, 37 mbar for LPG
Inspect electrode gap: 3-4mm from burner (use feeler gauge)
Test ignition lead: <200Ω resistance, no visible cracks/tracking
Remove and empty condensate trap, clean if necessary
Clean burner and flame sense electrode with wire brush
Check flame rectification circuit: microamp reading when flame present
Reset boiler after repairs - lockout resets after successful ignition
possibleCauses: No gas supply or gas valve closed
Gas pressure too low (<18 mbar at burner)
Ignition lead failure (high resistance or tracking)
Flame sense electrode contaminated or incorrectly positioned
L2.solution: Address cause of ignition failure: adjust electrode gap to 3-4mm, replace ignition lead if faulty, empty condensate trap, or replace gas valve if coil faulty. After fixing root cause, reset boiler to clear lockout.

L6.description: False flame detection / Flame before gas on
diagnosticSteps: Power OFF boiler - this is a safety-critical fault
Inspect flame sense electrode for contamination - clean with wire brush
Check electrode gap and position per manufacturer spec
Inspect PCB for water damage, corrosion, or burn marks
Test gas valve: should have NO continuity across solenoid when powered off
Check for gas smell at burner when boiler off (gas valve leak)
Test flame rectification circuit with boiler powered but NOT firing
Inspect electrode lead for cracks, tracking, or damaged insulation
possibleCauses: Flame sense electrode contaminated or incorrect gap
Water ingress on PCB causing false rectification signal
Faulty gas valve allowing gas through when closed
Electrode lead tracking or poor insulation
Burner contamination causing phantom flame signal
L6.solution: SAFETY CRITICAL: False flame detection indicates unsafe condition. Clean flame electrode. If PCB shows water damage, replace PCB. If gas valve allows gas through when closed, replace gas valve immediately. Do NOT operate boiler until fault resolved.
